meanings.definition: Shock or excite (someone) into taking action.
meanings.sent1: The inspiring speech managed to galvanise the audience into standing up for what they believed in.
meanings.sent2: The urgent call to action galvanised the community to come together and make a difference.
meanings.sent3: The unexpected plot twist in the movie galvanised the viewers, leaving them on the edge of their seats.
meanings.sent4: The sudden thunderstorm seemed to galvanise the sleepy town into a frenzy of activity.
meanings.sent5: The passionate performance by the singer galvanised the crowd, filling them with energy and enthusiasm.

meanings.definition: Coat (iron or steel) with a protective layer of zinc.
meanings.sent1: The workers carefully galvanised the metal beams to prevent rusting and corrosion.
meanings.sent2: The company decided to galvanise the fence to ensure it would withstand the harsh weather conditions.
meanings.sent3: The old car was lovingly restored, with the owner choosing to galvanise the metal parts for added protection.
meanings.sent4: The blacksmith used a special technique to galvanise the sword, making it both strong and durable.
meanings.sent5: The shipbuilders knew they had to galvanise the hull to keep it safe from the salty sea water.

meanings.definition: To stimulate or arouse to activity.
meanings.sent1: The cheerful music seemed to galvanise the children, who started dancing and playing around.
meanings.sent2: The coach's pep talk before the game galvanised the team, boosting their morale and determination.
meanings.sent3: The smell of freshly baked cookies galvanised the sleepy dog, who suddenly perked up and wagged its tail.
meanings.sent4: The colorful artwork on the walls galvanised the students, inspiring them to create their own masterpieces.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's praise and encouragement galvanised the shy student, giving them the confidence to speak up in class.
